questions.question: What is the time complexity of binary search?
questions.explanation: Binary search halves the search space at each step, resulting in logarithmic time complexity.

questions.question: Which data structure uses FIFO (First In, First Out) ordering?
questions.explanation: A queue follows FIFO ordering where the first element added is the first one removed.

questions.question: What is the worst-case time complexity of inserting an element at the beginning of an array?
questions.explanation: Inserting at the beginning requires shifting all existing elements one position to the right.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of linked list?
questions.explanation: Parallel Linked List is not a standard linked list type. The standard types are singly, doubly, and circular linked lists.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of children a node can have in a binary tree?
questions.explanation: By definition, each node in a binary tree can have at most two children (left and right).

questions.question: Which traversal visits the root node first, then left subtree, then right subtree?
questions.explanation: Preorder traversal follows: Root -> Left -> Right.

questions.question: A hash table with a good hash function has an average-case lookup time complexity of:
questions.explanation: With a good hash function and low collision rate, hash table lookups are O(1) on average.

questions.question: Which data structure is used in BFS (Breadth-First Search)?
questions.explanation: BFS uses a queue to explore nodes level by level in a graph or tree.

questions.question: What is the space complexity of a recursive function with depth d?
questions.explanation: Each recursive call adds a frame to the call stack, so space complexity is proportional to the maximum depth.

questions.question: Which sorting algorithm has the best average-case time complexity?
questions.explanation: Merge Sort has O(n log n) average-case complexity, which is better than the O(n^2) of Bubble, Selection, and Insertion sorts.

questions.question: What is a complete binary tree?
options: Every node has exactly two children
All levels are fully filled except possibly the last, which is filled from left to right
All leaves are at the same level
The tree has the minimum possible height
questions.correct_answer: All levels are fully filled except possibly the last, which is filled from left to right
questions.explanation: A complete binary tree fills each level left to right, with all levels full except possibly the last.

questions.question: Which data structure is best for implementing an undo feature?
questions.explanation: A stack's LIFO (Last In, First Out) property is ideal for undo operations, where the most recent action is undone first.
